comments:
Eclipse R3.1M6
WTP 1.0M4
Tomcat 5.0.28

Each time you close Eclipse, the classpath info of WebProjects associated to
Tomcat is lost.

You get this exception when you start Eclipse again and you expand the web
project (in project view), or you go to Java Buid Path in properties of the project.

.log file shows this exception:

java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.

The workaround I found is: Window -> Preferences -> Server -> Installed Runtimes
-> Select jakarta-tomcat-5.0.28 -> Edit... -> And not touching anything press
Finish button. The problem is fixed until you close again Eclipse.

Regards,

   Chemi.

This behavior suggests something is corrupt, but I'm not able to duplicate it 
to determine what.  Could you repeat this test case on a fresh workspace and 
attach a zip of it to this bug so I can try to determine what the problem is?  
Thanks.

Larry, I have sent a workspace directly to your email. The workspace size was
4Mb and BugZilla supports just 2Mb.

It is a new fresh workspace with a single Web Project with an empty servlet and
empty JSP and a Tomcat 5.0.28 server. Just with that, each time I restart
Eclipse, the classpath information of that project is lost.

My environment is:
- Windows XP
- Eclipse R3.1M6
- WTP 1.0M4
- Tomcat 5.0.28 (but I have seen same problem with Tomcat 4.1.31)

Regards,

   Chemi.

BTW, I forgot to mention that I have seen several people in the forum with the
same problem using the same versions...

Regards,

  Chemi.

I haven't identified the exact bug yet, but I have determined that it is the 
use of the "Search..." button when creating Tomcat runtimes that results in 
this behavior.  The internal "id" for the runtime is set to the location of 
the Tomcat runtime.  When this "id" is used in the project's ".runtime" file, 
it doesn't work successfully.

For now, don't use the "Search..." button, but create your Tomcat runtimes 
manually.

The root of this issue is that the initialize() method of 
o.e.jst.server.core.internal.RuntimeClasspathContainerInitializer's uses the 
following to obtain the runtime:

    String runtimeId = containerPath.segment(2);
    if (runtimeId != null)
        runtime = ServerCore.findRuntime(runtimeId);

This implies that the ID for the runtime should parse into a single path 
segment, not multiple segments like the one supplied by the current 
getRuntimeFromDir() method of TomcatRuntimeLocator.  The following patch 
substitutes "_" and "-" for path separators and ":", respectively, to convert 
the absolute path of the runtime into an acceptable ID.

Created an attachment (id=21622)
Patch to o.e.jst.server.tomcat.core.internal.TomcatRuntimeLocator to generate
an appropriate ID
Changed Version field given new release numbering.
